Community and Home-Based Elderly Care and 
Health Care Services in Xiangyang

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help develop a model for an 
effective coordination mechanism between elderly care and health care services, focusing on the 
community and home levels, in Xiangyang Municipality, Hubei Province, the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC). The model will draw upon an analysis of available resources on links between 
elderly  care  and  health  care  services,  institutional  arrangements  for  effective  coordination, 
international experiences, and capacity building requirements. The TA is included in the list of 
projects agreed between the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the PRC Government on 
22 January 2020.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The PRC’s population is aging rapidly, with 166.6 million people aged 65 and over in 2018, 
and an aging rate (the proportion of people aged 65 or older to the total population) of 11.9%.2 
The increase in the ratio of the population aged 80 or older is expected to accelerate from about 
1.8% in 2020 to more than 7.5% in 2050.3 The demand for elderly care is highly age-dependent 
and rises with longevity. The expected change in the demographic structure indicates that 
demand  for  care  will  continue  to  accelerate  in  the  PRC.  Rapidly  aging  populations  are 
accompanied by increases in aging-associated diseases. Elderly people typically have chronic 
diseases  and  experience  multiple  morbidities.  The  primary  cause  of  elderly  people’s  care 
dependence is the loss of physical function resulting from chronic disease and impairments 
associated with aging.4 In addition, many elderly people have complex cases of multiple chronic 
diseases and physical and/or cognitive disabilities. Those elderly people would require both 
elderly care and health care services to sustain their daily living.5 
 
3.  Elderly  people  account  for  an  increasing  percentage  of  hospitalization,  and  those 
discharged are often functionally frail.6 In transition from hospitals, elderly care institutions, and 
homes, elderly people are vulnerable and at risk of experiencing fragmented care.7 Frail elderly 
people are often unprepared to face the challenges associated with continued care needs after 
hospitalization.  After  being  discharged  from  hospitals,  elderly  people  with  multiple  chronic 
conditions still require post-acute care and rehabilitation to stabilize their functions, along with 
continued care to retain and maintain their daily living. A coordination system that effectively links 
acute phase care, post-acute care, rehabilitation, and elderly care (covering institutional care as 
well as community and home-based care) is key to ensuring continuity across elderly care and 
health care services and attaining better health outcomes for elderly people. 
 
4.  The Government of the PRC has recognized the importance of addressing the division 
between elderly care and health care services. A key policy, jointly issued by 10 ministries in 2015, 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 19 October 2020. 
2  National Bureau of Statistics of China. 2019. China Statistical Yearbook 2019. Beijing. 
3  C. Textor. 2020. Aging Population in China—Statistics and Facts. Statistica. 23 March.  
4  World Health Organization. 2015. China Country Assessment Report on Ageing and Health. Switzerland. 
5  Elderly care services, which is also called long-term care services, include care for activities of daily living, dementia 
care, and non-intensive rehabilitation such as occupational therapy. Health care services include clinical, medical, 
nursing home care services, and physical therapy.  
6  Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 2015. Hospitalizations Among the Elderly. Journal of American Medical 
Association. 
7  E. A. Coleman. 2003. Falling Through the Cracks: Challenges and Opportunities for Improving Transitional Care for 
Persons with Continuous Complex Care Needs. Wiley Online Library. 26 March.

2   
provides guidance on the integration of elderly care and health care services;8 another policy was 
issued  by  12 ministries  and  committees  in  2019. 9  Following  guidance  from  the  central 
government, Xiangyang Municipal Government issued a policy on elderly care and health care 
integration in 2017.10 
 
5.  However, proper integration of elderly care and health care services has not progressed 
in Xiangyang due to several constraints. A key issue is that the policy primarily focuses on the 
institutional level, while greater attention is needed to respond to the needs and services at the 
community and home levels. The financial resources are limited for community and home-based 
care services. Furthermore, the policy appears to focus more on physical integration by expanding 
elderly care institutions’ scope to include health care services, whereas limited attention is 
provided to establish a coordination mechanism between health care and elderly care. 
 
6.  Institutional coordination has also been ineffective, which limits the timely referral between 
elderly care and health care. The role of the municipal government in the provision of coordinated 
care services is unclear, and institutional arrangements across those sectors have not been 
established. Furthermore, elderly care and health care providers do not have financial incentives 
to coordinate their services. Because of unclear lines of responsibility in the municipal government, 
coordination among bureaus is not clearly defined, which critically limits the capacity of the 
municipal government to effectively manage the coordination of care services at the community 
and home levels. 
 
7.  Xiangyang Municipality needs to develop a coordination mechanism for elderly care and 
health care services, particularly at the community and home levels. An ongoing ADB TA project 
is supporting the development of an elderly care policy framework at the central government 
level.11 ADB has also been supporting local governments to strengthen their capacity to provide 
and manage care services.12 Building on that support with attention on institutional care, this TA 
will continue and complement ADB’s support by focusing on coordination of community and 
home-based elderly care and health care services. It is aligned with the pillar on inclusive growth 
of ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–2020; and the Operational Plan for 
Health, 2015–2020 which has elderly care as a focus area.13 It is also in line with ADB’s Strategy 
2030 as it supports operational priority 6 (strengthening governance and institutional capacity) 
through strengthening service delivery.14 Coordination at the community and home levels is a key 
issue not only for Xiangyang but also for many other cities in the PRC. Further, it is a critical issue 
for many aging societies. The TA will have a knowledge transfer impact not only in other cities in 
the PRC but also in other developing member countries facing population aging challenges 
through TA seminars and dissemination of knowledge products.  
 
8  Government of the PRC, State Council. 2015. Circular on Accelerating Health Care and Elderly Care Integration. 
Beijing (in Chinese).   
9  Government of the PRC, State Council. 2019. Opinion on Deepening the Development of Health Care and Elderly 
Care Integration. Beijing (in Chinese). 
10  Xiangyang Civil Affairs Bureau. 2017. Methods for Implementing Health and Elderly Care Services in Xiangyang. 
Unpublished. 
11  ADB. People’s Republic of China: Policy and Capacity Building for Elderly Care. 
12  ADB. People’s Republic of China: Strategic Elderly Care Services Development in Yichang; ADB. People’s Republic 
of  China:  Hebei  Elderly  Care  Development  Project;  ADB.  People’s  Republic  of  China:  Hebei  Elderly  Care 
Development Project;  ADB. People’s Republic of China: Hubei Yichang Comprehensive Elderly Care Demonstration 
Project; ADB. People’s Republic of China: Demonstration of Guangxi Elderly Care and Health Care Integration and 
Public–Private Partnership Project. 
13  ADB. 2016. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2016–2020—Transforming Partnership: 
People’s Republic of China and Asian Development Bank. Manila; and ADB. 2015. Operational Plan for Health, 
2015–2020. Manila. 
14 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: accessibility to coordinated care services in 
Xiangyang  Municipality  improved  (footnote  10).  The  TA  will  have  the  following  outcome: 
coordination of elderly care and health care services at community and home levels in Xiangyang 
improved.15  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Status of coordination among care services for elderly people examined. 
Under output 1, the TA will examine the (i) status of long-term care services focusing on the 
community and home levels in Xiangyang;16 (ii) status of health care services at the community 
and home levels and the health care-referral system in Xiangyang; (iii) status of coordination, if 
any, between long-term care and health care services; (iv)  financial mode, if any, for long-term 
care services at the community and home levels, and the financial mode for health care services 
in Xiangyang; and (v) impact of those financial modes in coordinating long-term care and health 
care services, including an analysis of financial incentives or disincentives for coordination. Based 
on the above, a report on the status of coordination between elderly care and health care services 
focusing on the community and home levels in Xiangyang Municipality will be prepared.17  
 
10.  Output 2: Model for coordination between elderly care and health care services 
produced.  Building  on  the  analyses  of  output  1  and  taking  international  practices  into 
consideration, the TA will analyze the (i) types of elderly people who are at risk of breakdowns in 
care and would benefit from coordinated elderly care and health care services, particularly at the 
community and home levels; (ii) types of services that would most require coordination of elderly 
care and health care services; (iii) key players in the provision of services across elderly care and 
health care; (iv) institutional arrangements needed for coordination; (v) a potential financial 
framework to incentivize coordination; and (vi) municipal government’s role in establishing a 
coordination mechanism. The interface issue across various information and communication 
technology systems of relevant bureaus and agencies will also be examined. Based on the above, 
a report on a model for coordinating elderly care and health care services focusing on community 
and home levels in Xiangyang Municipality will be prepared.18  
 
11.  Output 3: Knowledge and management capacity in coordinating elderly care and 
health  care  services strengthened.  Output 3  will  provide  opportunities to strengthen the 
knowledge  and  management  capacity  of  relevant  bureaus  and  agencies  of  Xiangyang 
Municipality in (i) elderly care and health care service provision, particularly at the community and 
home levels; (ii) needs for effective coordination; and (iii) a functional coordination mechanism of 
care services through training, international and domestic study visits, and workshops. 
 
 
15 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
16 Civil society organizations could be care service providers at the community and home levels. Their potential active 
role in care service provision will be analyzed under this TA project. Care services at the community level means that 
the elderly people visit a care center or community center, and receive long-term care, rehabilitation, etc. For home-
based care, providers, such as caregivers and nurses, visit the homes of elderly people to provide care services.  
17 Long-term care services are also called elderly care services, as described in the scope of care services in footnote 5. 
18 The coordination mechanism will consider the processes, methods, and tools required for coordination, as well as 
institutional arrangements. The model will be prepared with the Xiangyang Civil Affairs Bureau, which is responsible 
for elderly care development in the municipality.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $265,000, of which $250,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space for meetings, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. The executing agency will be the Xiangyang Municipal 
Government  through  the  Xiangyang  project  management  office,  which  will  coordinate  with 
municipal  bureaus  and  agencies  to  carry  out  the  training  and  workshops  under  the  TA. 
Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements

ADB = Asian Development Bank, TA = technical assistance.  
Source: ADB. 
 
15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated procurement staff instructions.19 
Individual  consultants  will  be  recruited  to  provide  3.0  person-months  of  international  and 
3.0 person-months of national consulting inputs. A national consulting firm, with total inputs of 
16.5 person-months, will be recruited using consultants’ qualifications selection method.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Support for Development of a Coordination 
Mechanism  for  Community  and  Home-Based  Elderly  Care  and  Health  Care  Services  in 
Xiangyang, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
19 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

6  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Status of coordination among care services for elderly people examined 
1.1  Complete analysis of elderly care and health care and status of coordination between elderly care and 
health care services by Q3 2021. 
1.2   Complete analysis of the financial modes and its impact on the coordination of long-term care and 
health care services by Q3 2021. 
1.3  Finalize report on the status of coordination between elderly care and health care services by 
Q4 2021. 
2.  Model for coordination between elderly care and health care services produced 
2.1   Complete analysis of key issues related to coordinating elderly care and health care by Q2 2022. 
2.2  Complete analysis of international best practices by Q2 2022. 
2.3  Finalize report on a model for coordinating elderly care and health care services by Q4 2022. 
3.  Knowledge and management capacity in coordinating elderly care and health care services 
strengthened 
3.1  Prepare detailed agenda and identify destination of study visits based on the agenda by Q1 2022. 
3.2   Conduct domestic and international study visits by Q3 2022. 
3.3  Organize training and workshops by Q3 2022.
